name: Prague
fun_fact: Fun fact: The Czech Republic has led the world in beer consumption per capita every single year since 1993. In 2005, Czechs consumed a record 163.5 liters (327 beers) per person. Beer is cheaper than water in Prague - a pint of local beer costs about 14 koruna while bottled water costs 35 koruna. hero_dishes.description: Creamy soup with mushrooms, potatoes, and a poached egg, offering unique balance of tangy and savory flavors from fresh dill.

signature_drinks.name: Pilsner Urquell
signature_drinks.description: The world's first golden pilsner beer, created in 1842 in Plze≈à. The original light-colored lager that inspired imitations worldwide.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Pilsner Urquell is served throughout Prague at traditional hospodas (pubs) and beer gardens, always fresh and cold. Czechs drink it leisurely over hours of conversation, often accompanied by traditional dishes like goulash, sausages, or sv√≠ƒçkov√°. U Zlat√©ho Tygra is a local favorite for pairing pilsner with authentic food. The Pilsner Urquell Experience museum opened in Prague in 2023, showcasing brewing history.

signature_drinks.name: Czech Beer (Gambrinus, Staropramen, Budvar, Bernard)
signature_drinks.description: Major Czech beer brands beyond Pilsner Urquell. Gambrinus is consumed in largest quantity, but many Czechs are partial to various local brews.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beer gardens are integral to social life in Czech cities, providing relaxed environments for friends and families to enjoy brews for hours. Czech beer culture dates to 993 AD with over 1,000 years of brewing heritage. U Flek≈Ø microbrewery has the longest continuous brewing history in Prague since 1499.

signature_drinks.name: Becherovka
signature_drinks.description: Herbal liquor from Karlovy Vary spa town using 20+ herbs and spices (cinnamon, anise, clove). Tastes 'like Christmas' and has been popular for medicinal use since the 19th century.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Any local pub offers Becherovka, typically served as a digestif after heavy Czech meals. The complex herbal blend is considered both medicinal and celebratory, reflecting Czech spa town wellness traditions.
